SP.P: Rest satisfy'd, my Lords, they both shall be my Charge; I will observe him unperceiv'd; and give you timely Notice, if your Aid's requir'd. But haste, my Lords, for here you must not stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Be gone, my Zueski, for shou'd he see you here, you irrecoverably were lost indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: We will retire to Rureck's Palace; and you my Zar∣rianna, once play the Hypocrite, and sooth him into softness, by a seeming Submission to his Will; as far as may consist with fair Marina's Safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: I'll try how well I can dissemble, tho' 'tis a Task un∣welcome to my Nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Alas, he's come already.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Have you consider'd yet, fair Zarrianna, whether that Beauty, given by Heaven to be ador'd by all, will best be∣come a Throne or Sepulchre? For know, proud Maid, my fi∣nal Resolution is to make thee mine; for if you'll consent to be possest by me, you ne'er shall be another's.

SP.SPEAKER: Zar.
SP.P: The time you graciously were pleas'd to give for my Determination is not yet expir'd; I had your Royal Word that you wou'd patiently attend my Answer till night, till then I beg, you wou'd deferr to know my Resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: If you till then, will give me Hopes to live on, I do agree to what you say I promis'd. Say, lovely Zarrianna, shall I call you mine? May I have leave to hope that you'll yet be kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Zar.
SP.P: Alas, most Royal Sir, I canot yet so much forget my Zueski, as I ought, but will endeavour to be grateful to you. Time must be given me. [Sighs.] Which has effected harder things, than 'tis for a poor weak defenceless Maid to love a young and glorious Emperour.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Oh Zarrianna! Can this Change be real! Thou'st given me Hopes enough to feast my Soul. If this small Shew of Kindness can raise me to such Joys, what will the full Pos∣session of all thy wondrous Beauty?

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: I am not worthy, Sir, of all the vast Expressions of your Love; but if you so esteem me, I beg the fair and inno∣cent Marina, may not be made a Sacrifice to my advance∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P:
Let her then shew the Duty of a Muscovy Wife, and condescend to what I'd have her do. I do not seek her Life,
'tis what her obstinate Perverseness will force me to. What say you, Madam? Is't Life or Death you chuse?

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: I will consider, Sir, and give my Answer at the time prefixt. I am unwilling to be an Obstacle to Zarrianna's Hap∣piness who best deserves the Honour you intend her; tho' I must think I have not merited such Treatment as my Fortune deals me, I have not any way deserv'd your most unkind and cruel Usage of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: 'Tis false, thou hast: Why were you not as fair as Zarrianna?

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Love is not always guided by most Merit. It is the Work of Chance. If I have any Power with you, I do in∣treat you'd give the wrong'd Marina the time you promis'd her to fix her Resolutions.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: You must and shall command in every thing; I hope you mean me fair, for if you do not, you know I can and will revenge my self severely.

SP.SPEAKER: Zar.
SP.P: These Threats do ill become a Lover's Mouth: You shall have no such Causes given to shew that Power.

SP.SPEAKER: Deme.
SP.P: Forgive me, Zarrianna, if such an unexpected Bles∣sing creates some Jealousie. To Marina.] I give you, Madam, at my Fair Mistresses Request, the Time you do demand; and you, my Zarrianna, when next I see you, I hope will be ne∣ver to part again.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: The hated Task I have at last perform'd, as if I long had practis'd the Trade of well-dissembling.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: You have prevented now th' impending Storm, which will return on us with greater Force, if not releiv'd be∣fore the time which he has limited.

SP.SPEAKER: Zar.
SP.P: Fear not, dear Madam, whilst Alexander and Zueski is so near, we cannot fail of Succour.

DIV3.L: If they succeed, all Fears of Death are past;
And if they fail, we can but dye at last.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Why is it, that Happiness and Greatness must be In∣consistent things? Why did I not secluded from this busie World, choose there in peace to pass my guiltless Days, pre∣fer a Life recluse with Innocence, and not a left it to Hea∣ven's avenging Hands? My Woman's Fears betray'd me to own this base Impostor for my Son; Why did I not at first detect the Cheat? Better I had dy'd to save my ruin'd Country, which now grieves under his oppressing Yoak.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: Mosco, you know, receiv'd him, as their titular An∣gel, with such unanimous and universal Pleasure, that had you then put the least Check to the o'reflowing Torrent of their unruly Joy, you'd only thrown away your Life, with∣out the least redress to your unhappy Country. Now is the time to give a helping Hand, to pull the Usurper down. The People now with heavy Groans do feel the burden of his op∣pressing Yoak, and will look kindly up to a Deliverer, to free them from the Curse of Galling Slavery. I must as long as possible, preserve the Tyrant's good Opinion of my Faith to him. Therefore, 'tis needful, Madam, that you get his leave upon some feign'd pretext, to visit Marina, and Zarrianna in the Castle, where you shall be secur'd from his pernicious Practices against your sacred Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: You speak as if you knew he had designs against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: Old honest Fedor has confest as much, and him he would have made the cursed Instrument of your Destruction, which he refusing with all the Detestation which became an honest Man, and such a hellish Crime, he sought to stifle the Secret in his Blood, which he by provident and timely care escap'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: What will not such a faithless Tyrant do, restrain'd by neither humane nor sacred Laws? Yet my own private Wrongs I patiently cou'd bear, but must not see my Friends and Country destroy'd by his accursed Power: Oh say, good Bosman, what is to be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: That, Madam, you shall know, use but your Arts to get into the Castle, where you will find a Strength sufficient to defend you there, and to dethrone the Tyrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I've thought upon a way which will, no doubt, prevail, as best agreeing with his brutish Pleasure; and see, as if his Destiny was hurrying him on, he come this way; let us retire a little and observe him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: She yields, she yields, I saw it in her Eyes, saw there the melting tenderness of her soft yielding Heart: Oh power of Empire, too great, too glorious, and too much to be re∣sisted by weak feeble Woman; I have her in my Arms, me∣thinks I'm rifling all her wondrous Treasures, and see [In Transport.] her blustring Beauties at the Conqueror's Mercy, who all in Raptures, in Extasies of Pleasure seizes the trembling Prey, and dyes with Transports of unruly Joys. Oh won∣derful effect of powerful Love, I am no more the Unrelent∣ing Cruel, proud Demetrius, but am all soft, all gentle and forgiving. This was the most substantial good I sought for in a Crown, to have all things subservient to my Will; and all my sensual Appetites regal'd by Pleasures uncontroul'd, could my wise Father confin'd my Soul as well as Body within the narrow limits he prescrib'd, I might ha' past my unregard∣ed Days in an obscure Retreat, and dy'd forgotten and neg∣lected, lain by after Ages; but my bold Actions will ever now Immortalize my Name. Shew me the Man like me, who dar'd to personate a Prince I never saw: What were the Grecian Conquerors, or Roman Caesars, to come in Competition with my Actions, they who had long been train'd to Arms, and bred up in the Trade of War; no wonder if they grew pro∣ficients in it: But I, whose Business ever was my Pleasures, to leap from a poor unobserv'd Monk into a glorious Throne; by Heav'n 'twas boldly done. [He turns and sees Bos. and Soph.] Sure they have not overheard me. [To them.] I did not see you Madam, I hope you have not long attended. Bosman. Why did not you acquaint me the Empress was here?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: You saw us as we enter'd, Royal Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Yes, my Demetrius, just the very Moment. Good Heav'ns, that I must still thus play the Hypocrite. [Aside.] I grieve, my Son, to hear the strange Disorders of your Family, caus'd by the Perverseness of Marina; where's the Advantage Kings have above common Men; but to have Power, to make themselves obey'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: And so I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: 'Tis fit you should. Yet, my Demetrius, I wou'd not have you tax'd with Cruelty, but trye all means, by fair and gentle ways, to win her to consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: I have, and threatnings too, which yet has no ef∣fects; I've given her till Night, to fix her Resolutions. If then they prove not Consonant to my Desire, she shall not live another.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I will, if you think fit, endeavour to bring her stub∣born Will to a Compliance with you; Women on Women have most prevailing Arts.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: That will but still increase her Pride, and make her more boldly Obstinate, beleiving that I fear her.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Trust me my Son, we Women know a thousand win∣ning Arts, you cannot condescend to; she shall not so much as think I have your Leave for what I undertake; Bosman shall say he privately unknown to you, at my Request, convey'd me to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: It is not fit I should deny you any thing you conde∣scend to ask; Bosman, wait on the Empress to the proud Ma∣rina, and you immediately return to me; I've Business of Im∣portance with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: I shall obey you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: So, she has catch'd her self in her own Trap; I fear this Bosman is too honest for my Purpose; but yet I'll try him, and if I find he hesitates upon't; I will proceed with him in such a way, shall spoil his telling Tales.

DIV3.P: I'm thinking Bosman, how very hard it is, that Greatness only shou'd exempted be from Friendship. I, who tho' born to sway, and am the Potent'st Monarch of all Europe, still want that Happiness of a faithful Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos. Aside.]
SP.P: What can he mean? I hope he has no Inti∣mation of our Conspiracy. [To him. The awful Distance which by all is kept to our great Czars, to whom we all are Slaves, debarrs us from the Hopes of that high Honour, to which no Subject never durst Aspire.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: But if an Emperour condescend, to make a private Man his Friend; it is not sure Presumption to accept it? How ought he, think you, to receive the Testimony of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: With such a Reverence as we may pay to Heav'n, with humble Love, and with a zealous Duty; with quick Obser∣vance of his least Commands, and hazarding Life, Fortunes, Honour, All, whene'er his Service needs them—[Aside.] I find he drives at something, and will, if possible, fathom his dark Designs.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Just, just such a Friend I want; and who so fit to make one, as the Man who understands the Merits that ought to qualifie him for such a Weighty Favour? Coud'st thou, my Bosman, be this Friend? Thy most aspiring Thoughrs can ne∣ver reach the Honours thou shalt meet, if, in return, thou can'st but love me so well as to obey my Orders, without dis∣puting them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: Your Majesty in all things may command your Bosman's faithful Service.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
Bos.
SP.P: Has it no Name? Speak boldly, Sir; I dare to execute whatever you command.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Would'st thou but bring a Balm to cure this Wound, thou wer't a Friend indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: Humanity to all, in any sort of Trouble, that Lesson sure must teach; but for a King and Friend, since you permit to use that sacred, but familiar, Name, I wou'd do [bowing] more than I can well express, to prove a just Pretence to that glorious Title.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P:
This, Bosman, is the proof I do require; to rid me of my my curst Domestick Plagues; Sophia and Marina by Poy∣son,
or any other secret Ways. Ha! thou start'st [Frowning.] Take heed thou hast not promis'd more than what you dare perform.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: Oh hellish Monster! [To him. Pardon, me, Roy∣al Sir; if I seem'd surpriz'd; it was not that I dare discant on your wise Resolutions, but fear you do it only to try how far my Zeal will carry me to your Service.

SP.SPEAKER: Deme.
SP.P: Then let me tell thee, Bosman, I am serious; I have some private Reasons to dispatch Sophia; Marina, you well know, obstructs my Happiness with Zarrianna; get it but hand∣somly, and all the Privacy that can be done, thou'st gain'd thy King for ever; and let it publickly be spread. Dispair 'twas forc'd Marina to do the Deed her self, for fear that Man∣zeck should by his Resentments interrupt my Joys with Zarri∣anna; I shall not be examin'd how old Sophia came by her long-expected Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: I can with Secresie and Speed perform the Deed. But one thing will be needful, to take off all Suspicion, which is, to have the Cossacks withdrawn from out the Castle, and let a Guard of Poles have the securing of it, of equal number with the Muscovites already there.

SP.SPEAKER: Deme.
SP.P: That may be hazardous, and may endanger their sei∣zing on the Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: That, Sir, shall be my Care: I will observe how they resent her Death; and if I find but the least Murmur, I soon you know Sir, can command such Forces as shall overpower theirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: I leave it to you then to act as you see Cause; tell Carclos 'tis my Orders that he withdraws his Cossacks: But let them be remov'd no farther than the middle of the City, where they will be at hand to give Assistance in any Exigent.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: I'll put all things in readiness, and then expect to hear your Will's obey'd. Aside.] Now perish, Tyrant, by thy own pernicious Wiles.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.L: When this h'as done, the next shall be my part,
I'll stab the Deed, in his unthinking Heart;
The Treason we approve, the Traytor hate;
He, in their Deaths, determines his own Fate.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT V. Scene I.
DIV3.STAGE: Shouts and Alarms within. Enter Zueski, Manzeck, Basilius, Rureck, and Zaporjus.

SP.SPEAKER: Manz.
SP.P: THese Cossack's are brave and daring Fellows; they fought with such undaunted Resolution, that had their Cause been equal to their Valour; they must have vanquish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rure.
SP.P: This was a Counterplot we were not well aware of: Had we not been prepar'd for all Contingencies, it had un∣done us.

SP.SPEAKER: Basi.
SP.P: He'd some Design, no doubt, unknown to us, for which he had conceal'd these Cossack's in his Palace.

SP.SPEAKER: Zap.
SP.P: They stood to the last single Soldier, and met their Deaths like Men resolv'd to dye; would the Impostor were as sure dispatch'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: 'Tis true, the Castle is securely ours; Zarrianna and Marina too are safe from his Tyrannick Rage. But if he so escapes us, we've done our Work by halves.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: My Lords, the Tyrant's fled where most we fear'd, and has an Asyle found within the Middle City, where he with utmost Diligence is fortifying himself against our Attacks. The Citizens with over-zealous Duty have promis'd him their Aid, but more for Fear than Love; being surrounded by ten Thousand Cossacks, who they well knew wou'd force 'em to Obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: How did he from the Castle so easily escape us? Art thou inform'd, good Bosman.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: Out of a Window of his own Apartment, where Car∣clos stood ready to receive him, and has convey'd him, where I fear he's now in too much Safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Manz.
SP.P: Let's pour in all our Forces to the City, and instant∣ly attack him, whilst Alexander and Bosman secure the Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Bass.
SP.P: Something must quickly be resolv'd; this Work begun must end with Victory, or our poor Country's Ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Rure.
SP.P: The best expedient can be found is instantly, being now the Dead of Night, to raise an Alarm, that the Cossacks are up in Arms to massacre the Muscovites▪ which soon will put the Citizens in Arms for their own Preservation, and will rea∣dily embrace the Offer of our Assistance to secure themselves: By this means, we may destroy the Guard in which the Ty∣rant puts his greatest Trust, and save the Blood of your Mus∣covian Subjects.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: I do approve your Counsel: Hast, give Word in e∣very Quarter; spread the fatal News; approaching Danger will give each Coward a daring Arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Rure.
SP.P: 'Tis done; swift as your Thoughts the dread Alarm flies.

SP.SPEAKER: Zap.
SP.P: Their Amazement will not give them time to rally; or, if they shou'd, for Carelos is a brave and great Commander, and will no way be wanting in the part of a Wise General, the City joining with us, we soon shall over-power them, and drive them out from Mosco and the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Bass.
SP.P: The Citizens, no doubt, will be enrag'd with Ter∣rour and Surprize; for tho' their Coward Natures wou'd shrink at any brave and daring Enterprize, will, to secure themselves in Heat of Blood, extirpate, if possible, the very Name of Cossacks.

SP.SPEAKER: Manz.
SP.P: I'll give the same Alarm in all the other Parts of Mos∣co, and with my Forces be ready to assist them. Let Bosman join with Alexander, to keep firm the Castle; the Tyrant may attempt there to secure himself. The Poles I know with all Alacrity will be commanded by my Alexander, and pay him, as they ought, a ready Duty; and Bosman's Presence will best engage the Faith of his Muscovites; who may perhaps not be well pleas'd to obey so young a General, and one that is a Stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: You Counsel well, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: The Night wears on apace: Heark already the Swords Clangors, and their dying Screams o'retake us: Let's meet and conquer: Bear down the Tyrant and his Friends before us.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Ruine and Death where-e're I turn pursue and find the lost Demetrius. Oh Zarrianna, she is the Cause of my Destruction: Yet I love her still, and more regret the Loss of her than Empire. Fool that I was, to be perswaded by her false deluding Arts, and not have forc'd her when it was in my Power: That Power now is gone, and my more violent Desire remains. What are the feeble Succours of a Town, whilst a wide Empire still pouring Forces on must at last o're∣whelm me. Oh for a brave Revenge before I die: If die I must, cou'd I but crush old Manzeck with my Fall, and reach the Heart with this [Shews a Dagger] of his Imperious Daughter, force Zarrianna to my last Embraces, and see expi∣ring by my side, I cou'd resign contented my Life and Throne together.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Carclos hastily, his Sword drawn, with a Monk's Habit under his Arm.
DIV3.P: Ha! good Carclos, thou seem'st surpriz'd, as if some unex∣pected Accident had hasten'd thee to warn me of approaching Ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Alas, you're lost, Sir; the Hopes we plac'd in your poor faithful Cossacks are now destroy'd; and we have nothing else to do, but bravely seek a Death, which else will meet us here.

SP.SPEAKER: Deme.
SP.P: Are they revolted to the Enemy?

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Oh no, Sir; think not so meanly of your Cossacks Love; more than Ten thousand of them fill the Streets of Mosco with their dead and mangled Carcasses, their Blood in Streams flows like an Inundation, murder'd by a cursed Strata∣gem of the Enemy; the City in all parts is up in Arms, and nothing to be seen but Horror and Confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Deme.
SP.P: Have the curst Citizens at last deceiv'd me, and giv'n up the City to my Foes?

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P:
What they have done was, as they thought, in their own just Defence: A false Alarm struck them all with Ter∣rour, and made them fall with an unbridl'd Fury on our Cos∣sacks, who unprepar'd, not thinking of any Foes within the
City, were all unarm'd excepting those who kept the Guard, and all dispers'd to rest their wearied Bodies, after the Fatigue of the preceeding Day, they fell by Thousands, e'er they were well awake.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Cannot you draw them Quarter'd in the City Royal, into a Body, and bring them to our Aid?

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Mosco has all receiv'd the same Alarm; the Arsenal they've surpriz'd, and all my faithful Soldiers partook of the same Fate, which we too shall meet, if here we stay; I have eight Thousand left in Columna, if thither we can escape, where we might rest secure, till from the Vkraine I could form a Body powerful enough to reinstate you in your lost Dominions.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Ha! What means these Shouts?

SP.SPEAKER: Offic.
SP.P: Fly, Sir, or you are lost; Zueski, by all the faithless Muscovites is saluted Czar, and all the City surrender'd to his Powers, and this way they're seeking you.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Zueski! Thou rav'st; he dy'd by my Commands: Would all my Enemies were as secure as he.

SP.SPEAKER: Offic.
SP.P: Believe me, Sir, however you were deceiv'd, he lives, and is e'er this enter'd the City, follow'd by all the Boy∣ers, and with the Acclamations of all Mosco.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: If this be true, I must be lost indeed. Oh Carclos, Carclos, something worse than Death wracks my proud Heart, and drinks the gushing Blood of thy most wretched Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: What is't, my Royal Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Mock me no more with Royalty; I am a Slave, the worst of Slaves; Slave to my Passion; Oh! I must dye, and leave Zarrianna to be possest by Zueski; there's the sting! Had I lost my Empire for a brave-Revenge, or cur'd my Insa∣tiate Love; I shou'd have laugh'd at the Exchange. Now, I cou'd curse the cruel Pow'rs with invenom'd Teeth, tear up this solid Earth, and to the Centre sink a Fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Cursing kills not.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Marina too insults; the Imperious Fair Ones hug and clasp; Revel in Joys at the defeat of poor Demetrius.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Is it all you have left, to wish Revenge on these un∣grateful Women.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: It is, it is: And witness Heav'n or Hell, that thus inspires: Dole Fate but out to them the Dregs of Wrath thou pour'st on me, and I shall fall contented.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: A little Fort there still remains unattack'd, guarded by faithful Cossacks; a well-chosen trusty few; there we have room to dye, tho' not to conquer.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Ha Carclos, a Beam of Light arises, and strikes my Soul with Joy; a bloody gloom and crimson Stream dreadful∣ly glorious; it whisks like flaming Meteors round my Thoughts, gathers Revenge, and then contracted, set it in a Flame. If thou coud'st draw the Women thither, ha, Carclos, Marina the blooming Fair, the inviting Princess of the Northern World is thine, thy Prize; a Princess, I shou'd have languish'd for, had she not been thrown in my Arms, and that way made her Beauties cheap.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Agreed, Methinks with this great Enterprize, this stu∣pendious Wickedness, I am grown an Emperour, and we will know no more Distinction: How Riotous, how Glorious we shall grow in love with Death! Haste, this Man's your Guide.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: But how, dear Carclos, wilt thou effect it?

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: I saw just now in dire Confusions, a grey Bearded Priest peep out, and lift his wither'd Hands, and blest Rebel∣lion! then smil'd with a malicious Joy, and holy grin, to see my once Victorious Cossack's fall; I provok'd, struck my Stil∣letto to his Heart, that done, tore off his upper Garment, which I design'd for your escape: But a better Plot is laid, and in this Weed of Sanctity I will decoy the unwary Prin∣cesses. Manzeck and Zueski are too deep employ'd, and think 'em safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.

DIV3.L: Oh that the Sun, that ushers in the Light,
Might with me set in an Eternal Night.
May all the Orbs from their bright Seat be hurl'd,
And Desolation reign o'er all the World.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Draws, and discovers Sophia, Marina, Zarrianna in a Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: How happy is the humble Cottager, who never knows the Madness of Ambition? Wou'd I had been born a simple Shepherdess, or any other mean and lowly Maid; an humbler Fortune wou'd a suited better with my tender Nature; had I been such, I might have past my unenvy'd Days in an obscure Retreat, more to be valu'd than the anxious Cares of this exalted Greatness.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Blame not the choice of Heav'n, who made you what you are, and gave you Merit to justifie its Bounty; your Vertues would have shin'd so eminently bright, how e're obscurely plac'd, for all to wonder at; a Goodness less than yours cou'd not forgive the more than barbarous Usage you have met from a most base and undeserving Husband, but thus so deep∣ly to afflict your self for the Destruction of him who well de∣serves it; 'tis generous, and shews the noblest Nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarri.
SP.P: Let us forbear to triumph, Fate is yet at work; Zueski, Manzeck, and Alexander with Swords unsheath'd, are dealing Death around, and they may (avert it Heav'n) meet the Wounds they give.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Such were the Thoughts, that made me curse Am∣bitious Greatness; loss of Empire weighs not the least grain in my Esteem; but Oh Alexander! forgive me Heaven, if I sigh for him; here Sorrow rends my poor distracted Heart, to think my faithful Lover, and my faithless Husband are en∣gag'd; for if Demetrius falls by Alexander's Hand, Honour forbids me e'er to Crown the Conquerour.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: So nice a Vertue, and so chaste Mind, must needs be Heav'ns peculiar Care.

SP.SPEAKER: Offic.
SP.P: The Patriarch, Madam, waits in your Apartment with Business of Importance to acquaint your Majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph. to Marin.]
SP.P: Tell him I'll come. [Exit Officer.] You may expect I hither will return, and bring you word of what his News imports.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Carclos disguis'd in a Priest's Habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Beyond my Hopes they're here, and all alone, as I cou'd wish. Hail happy Pair, Auspicious Daughters, Hail, Manzeck and Zueski, to their Victorious Swords we owe our Liberty; Tyrants and Tyranny are now no more; the Bre∣thren's pious Pray'rs, with the poor help of twenty thousand Hands, has done the work of Heav'n.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Speak good Father, is Zueski safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Manzeck and Alexander, do they live? The wretch∣ed Demetrius what is his Fate?

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Demetrius o'rewhelm'd, amongst a heap of slain, is undistinguish'd bury'd, or alone escap'd, never to give ye Ap∣prehensions more; the rest are Conquerours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Alas, unhappy Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: So quick a Revolution is scarce to be believ'd; tir'd Eccho faints with Repetition of Zueski's Name and Emperor; but to secure Ten Thousand Soldiers led by Boris, still fond of his Name and Race, by me he humbly begs fair Zarrianna your Appearance on a little Fort, where Mosco with united Voice salutes him Lord of her, and all her Northern World.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Where is it, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Here, within the Castle; the Castle you know is yours. And with him Manzeck, who commands his injur'd Daughter to appear, to satisfie the Muscovites she is oppressed as well as they.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Come, dear Companion of my Prison, now let us mount to Joys.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Led by this Holy Man, I hope we cannot go a∣miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: My Royal Daughter, hasten; without here waits most faithful Guides.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: We follow, Father.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE A Fort.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P:
Oh the Wrack of Expectation! Not Empire, when opened with all its Glories to my View, not when united Kingdoms strove to call me Lord, stretch'd my expanded Soul
with half this terrible Delight. I hear 'em coming, and each Artery, like a Cable, holds my Heart firm to my stern pur∣pose.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: When, Father, shall we see a Friend? For yet I have not found a Face belonging to my Zueski.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Now Ladies, now my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr. Mari.
SP.P: Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Hear ye Cossacks, we have your Ransomes. Now double each Step, that leads to this abode of Death, and let 'em meet the Monster who ever dares approach us: Appear, my faithful lucky Carclos, and seize my Queen, my Empress.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Behold me, Sir, like you; all full of Rage and Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: What can the Tyrant mean? Help us Heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Help us, ye Powers!

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Ha, ha: No Help, nor Humane, nor Divine, shall now assist ye. Mark me, ye faithful last Reserve, when we have dispoil'd these stubborn Beauties of what they value most, their Honours, then the Toyes which now adorn 'em, the glittering Wealth of Mosco, enough to purchase Kingdoms, shall be yours in equal Plunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Oh take all before; strip us to shame, then tumble us headlong down; and glut your Rage with ought but loss of Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: And what art thou? What insolent Slave, who dar'st with impious Hands, to seize a free-born Princess?

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: I was the Creature of thy Emperour, his Partner now in the last Joys of Life, and then in Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Do not drag me so; if Death and Cruelty are in thy Nature, glut thy Rage quick, quick dispatch me; and I'll com∣plain no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Force 'em to the inmost Retreat; we dally here too long.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarri.
SP.P: Listen to me Demetrius, as you value Life; for sure 'tis terrible when the wicked dye. Upon the Turrets place us in the Victors view, and make your own Conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: My couragious Sister failing!

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Peace I wish this distracted World, and fain wou'd be the Oblation; give me a Window, Fire, Water, Swords, or any thing to be dispatch'd, and I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Offic.
SP.P: Oh Sir, by an Avenue to us unknown, Zueski and Bosman lead ten Thousand to these Ladies rescue.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Curse one their quick Intelligence; yet secure a while this Door, and their Revenge will come too late, whil'st ours is finish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: I know thee bold, with hazard of thy Life; when we are enter'd here, let down the massy Barrs.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Oh hold a Moment, hold as you are Sons of Women, hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
Dem.
SP.P: Not another Minute, to be Master of another World.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Help Zueski, help Heav'n, or Zarrianna dies.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: We have outstript our foremost Men, wing'd by fear for them we lov'd.—Oh horrour; Monster, quit that glori∣ous Prey, and defend thy Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: What upstart Fiend art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: Turn, Villain, turn, and see who 'tis that calls thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: I see 'tis he, who of all Mankind, I wish in Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: 'Tis thither thou art going.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarr.
SP.P: Assist, ye too long cruel Powers, Assist his Love and Truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Revenge me Heaven, on that unknown Instrument of Hell!

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Curse on my feeble Hand, that cou'd not reach thy Heart, as thou hast mine: Curse on your meeting Loves; may you still feel greater Torments than I fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Carc.
SP.P: Stay Emperour, stay Friend, 'tis Carclos, thy ever faith∣ful Slave thus follows thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: Come, ye choice Blessings, once and ever to our Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: May never Frights or Terrour disturb thy gentle Na∣ture more. Behold thy Tyrant Husband has found the just Reward of all his Crimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: Unhappy wretched Man, tho' thou no Pity had'st for me, I must lament thy Fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Teres.
SP.P: Oh my lov'd Royal Mistress! Thanks to Heav'n you are safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: Yes, and to this fair faithful Maid, who gave the A∣larm first; and with mistrustful Care found out you were be∣tray'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.L: Our Work is at an end, my Lords;
See where the Imposter breathless lies, expiating
His Crimes in his inglorious Blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.L: And behold all our Friends are come, to joyn our Joys,
But e'er they enter, let me do a Justice here.
Demetrius never did deserve a Tear from thee, Marina;
Therefore, my Son, [To Alex.] For now I call thee so indeed,
Take her, and with her, all the Blessings that are within
A Father's Power to give to his beloved Children.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Who has Marina, needs no other Blessing.
Thus, thus let me receive her, the only good
Heav'n and you can give me; now all my Sufferings are
Over-paid, since after all these Woes, I live to call
Marina mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.L: Some time allow'd to mourn these Storms of Fate;
And I need not tell my Alexander, I am wholly his.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter the Patriarch, Fedor, Bassilius, Rureck, Zaporjus, Citizens and Soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Bos.
SP.P: See Countrey-Men, your great Deliverer; he who no Pains nor Blood has spar'd to re-instate you in your Liberties, he who detected first the Cheat of this Impostor, and he who now has freed you from an usurping. Power of Tyranny and Injustice; through him your Ancient Priviledges you enjoy again; and who so fit to be your Emperour, as he who has a double Right to plead in my Rescuing you from Slavery, and being the undisputed Heir of great Basilovitz?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Citz.
SP.P: Let but the Empress Sophia disclaim this slain Deme∣trius for her Son; I know Lord Zueski's Right, and he shall have my Voice.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Citz.
SP.P: And mine.

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Citiz.
SP.P: And mine.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: And all.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.P: I do most solemnly disclaim him. Think if a Mother's Tenderness, cou'd see her Child lie wallowing in his Blood, and stand unmov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Long live Zueski, Emperour of all the Rushes.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.L: I thank you Country-men, and accept your Loves;
The Crown you in Justice have bestow'd on me,
And 'tis my undoubted Right.
But I receive it, only to lay it at these beauteous Feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Zarri.
SP.P: To him who best deserves it, I do restor't again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: May I be bold, amid'st this general Joy, to interrupt you, and beg you'd give Permission, that that unhappy Man may have the Rites of Funeral, and not be expos'd to the rude Insults of a merciless Rabble.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: You may command all in my Power to grant. Fedor, do you see him decently, but privately, interr'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fed.
SP.P: Your Majestly shall be obey'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Zuesk.
SP.P: Shine forth ye fair ones,

DIV3.L: And let the World, in your bright Glories see
The great Reward of vertuous Constancy:
At last to all a Halcyon Rest's restor'd,
And Muscovy now knows her rightful Lord.
